channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Antarctica vs. Science
item.description: For researchers using delicate, one-of-a-kind equipment, the extreme conditions at the bottom of the planet pose special challenges.
item.dc:creator: Robin George Andrews
item.media:description: A snowmobile towing sensitive equipment in Antarctica.

item.title: Your Chicken Is No Longer Pink. That Doesn’t Mean It’s Safe to Eat.
item.description: Next time you cook chicken, don’t rely on the color of the meat to tell you if it’s cooked enough to avoid food poisoning.
item.dc:creator: JoAnna Klein
item.category: Norwegian Institute of Food, Fisheries and Aquaculture Research
item.media:description: Chicken breasts turn from pink to white before reaching a temperature of 131 degrees, but aren’t considered safe until 158 degrees.

item.title: SpaceX to Bring Crew to Short-Staffed Space Station for Longer Stay
item.description: Two NASA astronauts will now stay for more than a month and not two weeks during their first flight aboard the Crew Dragon capsule.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: SpaceX’s Crew Dragon space capsule arriving at the launch site at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida in February.

item.title: 3 Africans in Mexico City Grave Tell Stories of Slavery’s Toll
item.description: The men might have been among the earliest to be stolen from their homeland and brought to the Americas.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas St. Fleur
item.media:description: The skulls and modified teeth of three people taken from Africa and buried hundreds of years ago in a mass grave in Mexico City.

item.title: The Sun Is a Bit Boring, Which May Make It Special
item.description: The sun seems a little less active than hundreds of similar stars in our galaxy, which could play a role in why life exists in our solar system.
item.dc:creator: Adam Mann
item.media:description: YAWN.

item.title: NASA Picks Moon Lander Proposals by SpaceX, Blue Origin, Others
item.description: It seems unlikely the space agency will meet President Trump’s goal of a return to the lunar surface by the end of 2024.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: The core stage of NASA’s Artemis rocket, which would take astronauts to the moon, at the Michoud Assembly Facility in New Orleans in January.

item.title: A Strange Dinosaur May Have Swum the Rivers of Africa
item.description: The Spinosaurus possessed a long, powerful tail. Paleontologists think the dinosaur used that to propel itself through water.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: An artist’s illustration of what Spinosaurus, one of the largest predatory dinosaurs yet found, may have looked like. A large, powerful tail may have been used for swimming.

item.title: Coronavirus Disrupts Illegal Wildlife Trafficking, for Now
item.description: Some conservationists see a chance to do lasting damage to criminal networks in the wake of the pandemic, but poaching may also rise.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer
item.media:description: A pangolin rescued from animal traffickers in Ha Tinh province, Vietnam, in July.

item.title: A Nest of Alien Asteroids Orbits Our Sun
item.description: Astronomers say they have found orphan rocks from another star, or stars, stashed in the outer solar system.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.category: Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society (Journal)
item.media:description: An illustration of the orbit of a Centaur asteroid.

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Governors Grapple With Protests and Reopenings
item.description: As scientists race to test a vaccine that may have to be taken annually, state officials are confronting growing impatience and ebbing respect for social distancing measures.
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times

item.title: The Covid-19 Riddle: Why Does the Virus Wallop Some Places and Spare Others?
item.description: Experts are trying to figure out why the coronavirus is so capricious. The answers could determine how to best protect ourselves and how long we have to.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech, Alissa J. Rubin, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iraqi border agents at the Zurbatiya border crossing with Iran. On the other side lies the largest epicenter of the virus in the Middle East. On the Iraqi side, there are relatively few cases.

item.title: Boris Johnson, China, Pompeo: Coronavirus World Updates
item.description: A global backlash is building against China, while government plans for reopening have prompted protests and sown confusion.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trevi Fountain in Rome, normally packed with people day and night, is nearly empty save for the those passing by with groceries.

item.title: Profits and Pride at Stake, the Race for a Vaccine Intensifies
item.description: Governments, companies and academic labs are accelerating their efforts amid geopolitical crosscurrents, questions about safety and the challenges of producing enough doses for billions of people.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, David D. Kirkpatrick, Carl Zimmer, Katie Thomas and Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: A laboratory technician in an isolation chamber testing a coronavirus vaccine in March in Belgrade, Serbia.

item.title: Coronavirus in the U.S.: Relaxed Rules and Warm Weather Test States
item.description: Congress declined the administration’s offer of rapid testing, saying tests were needed more elsewhere. Former President George W. Bush urged unity in a video message.
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Groups at Domino Park in Brooklyn on Saturday. Mayor Bill de Blasio pleaded with residents to resist the impulse to gather outdoors.

item.title: ‘Murder Hornets’ in the U.S.: The Rush to Stop the Asian Giant Hornet
item.description: Sightings of the Asian giant hornet have prompted fears that the vicious insect could establish itself in the United States and devastate bee populations.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:description: A dead Asian giant hornet rests on entomologist Chris Looney’s jacket in Blaine, Wash. The queens can grow to two inches long, and the hornets can wipe out a honeybee hive in a matter of hours.

item.title: Coronavirus World Updates: Italy Reports 474 New Deaths
item.description: As lockdowns begin to ease for millions of Europeans, Italy reports a spike in deaths. Migrants face roundups in Malaysia and surging infections in Singapore’s dormitories.
item.media:credit: Ashley Pon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students at a high school in Taipei, Taiwan, getting their temperature taken. Classes have been in session since late February.

item.title: Judge Vacates Oil and Gas Leases on 145,000 Acres in Montana
item.description: A federal judge, rapping the Trump administration for its weak environmental assessments, has vacated hundreds of oil and gas leases across a large swath of Montana.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Kristina Barker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Custer County in Montana is predominately covered by livestock grazing and agricultural use with drilling sites and resource extraction scattered throughout.

item.title: How Remdesivir, New Hope for Covid-19 Patients, Was Resurrected
item.description: The drug failed as a treatment for hepatitis and Ebola. With federal funding, scientists trained it on the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.category: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.media:description: Vials of remdesivir at a Gilead Sciences facility in La Verne, Calif.

item.title: Takuo Aoyagi, an Inventor of the Pulse Oximeter, Dies at 84
item.description: The medical device, which clips onto a patient’s finger, has saved millions of lives and is a vital tool in the fight against the novel coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: John Schwartz and Hikari Hida
item.media:description: Pulse oximeters are an ”indispensable addition to medicine,” and especially for patients suffering from Covid-19.

item.title: Is It Safe to Come Out of Lockdown? Check the Sewer
item.description: Wastewater could provide early, painless and localized data about the rise or fall of coronavirus levels.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: Researchers from Brazil’s National Institute of Science and Technology collected sewage samples to test for coronavirus in Belo Horizonte last month.

item.title: The Coronavirus Still Is a Global Health Emergency, W.H.O. Warns
item.description: Even as some governments contemplate reopening, the spread of the virus has accelerated in countries in Africa and South America.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:description: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, director-general of the W.H.O., during a coronavirus press briefing in Geneva in March.

item.title: An Eerily Prescient Pandemic Novel That’s Guaranteed to Terrify
item.description: In Lawrence Wright’s “The End of October,” a virulent flu races around the globe, killing millions and plunging society into disarray.
item.dc:creator: Douglas Preston

item.title: Blood Pressure Drugs Don’t Increase Coronavirus Risk, Studies Find
item.description: People taking widely used medicines did not face higher rates of infection or more severe illness, new research indicates.
item.dc:creator: Denise Grady
item.media:description: A study published Friday found that ACE inhibitors, ARBs, beta blockers and other commonly used blood pressure drugs do not increase the risk of coronavirus infection, or severe illness as a result of infection.

item.title: Coronavirus News and Updates
item.description: The F.D.A. issued emergency approval for an antiviral drug. High school seniors appear reluctant to commit to a college for the fall.

item.title: World Coronavirus Tracker: Britain, India, China
item.description: The W.H.O. extends the global health emergency as deaths near 240,000, and our New Delhi correspondent paints a portrait of a fearful city.
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Berlin laboratory testing samples sent by hospitals. Blood samples are critical in developing vaccines, cures, treatments and tests.

item.title: Labs Across U.S. Join Federal Initiative to Study Coronavirus Genome
item.description: The project, announced by the C.D.C., will help trace patterns of transmission, investigate outbreaks and map how the virus is evolving, which can affect a cure.
item.dc:creator: Sheri Fink
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Virus particles, marked in blue, that were taken from an early Covid-19 patient in the U.S.

item.title: During Coronavirus, Trump Sits on Clean Energy Loans
item.description: As Congress rushes out trillions of dollars to prop up businesses, the Energy Department is holding on to tens of billions in clean energy loans.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Energy Secretary Dan Brouillette on Capitol Hill in February.

item.title: Old Drugs May Find a New Purpose: Fighting the Coronavirus
item.description: A “drug repurposing” strategy uncovers dozens of compounds that have the unexpected potential to combat the virus.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.media:description: A scanning electron micrograph of a dying cell infected with coronavirus particles, in orange.

item.title: As Several States Loosen Rules, California Closes Some Beaches
item.description: New Jersey is now reporting more daily deaths than any other state. The federal government will increase inspections of nursing homes after a series of outbreaks.

item.title: As Georgia Reopens, Virus Study Shows Black Residents May Bear Brunt
item.description: A C.D.C. report released Wednesday suggests that the African-American community in the state is especially vulnerable to infection.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia has moved to restart the state’s economy.

item.title: Can Genetic Engineering Bring Back the American Chestnut?
item.description: The tree helped build industrial America before disease wiped out an estimated three billion or more of them. To revive their lost glory, we may need to embrace tinkering with nature.
item.dc:creator: Gabriel Popkin
item.category: State University of New York College of Environmental Science and Forestry
item.media:credit: John Chiara for The New York Times
item.media:description: An American chestnut near Rockport, Maine.

item.title: World Coronavirus Tracker: Live Coverage
item.description: The pandemic threatens to plunge half a billion people into poverty. The U.N. says it has raised just $1 billion of the $90 billion needed to aid poor regions.
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A slum in Mumbai. South Asia is expected to have its worst economic performance in 40 years because of the pandemic.

item.title: Emissions Declines Will Set Records This Year. But It’s Not Good News.
item.description: An “unprecedented” fall in fossil fuel use, driven by the Covid-19 crisis, is likely to lead to a nearly 8 percent drop, according to new research.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:description: A coal-burning power plant in Megalopolis, Greece, in March.

item.title: New Coronavirus Test Offers Advantages: Just Spit and Wait
item.description: Saliva tests like the one developed by Rutgers are less painful for patients and less risky to medical workers.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
item.media:description: Health workers administered a new saliva-based test for coronavirus in Edison, N.J., on April 15.

item.title: Energy Use in the Coronavirus Era: N.Y.C. Is Waking Up Later
item.description: Some 400 special electric meters in New York apartments provide a shifting view of power use while people are stuck inside.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: Overall consumption of electricity is down since the pandemic hit, but energy use in Manhattan apartments has gone up.

item.title: Remdesivir Shows Modest Benefits in Coronavirus Trial
item.description: Hope soared nonetheless. The F.D.A. is likely to issue an emergency approval, a senior official said.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata, Peter Baker and Noah Weiland
item.category: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.media:description: The antiviral drug remdesivir, developed to fight Ebola, is being evaluated as a treatment for Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus News and Updates
item.description: The early results of a trial of an experimental drug left White House officials hopeful. President Trump is pressing a crash vaccine program, but experts see risk in a rushed process.

item.title: ‘Will You Help Save My Brother?’: The Scramble to Find Covid-19 Plasma Donors
item.description: A doctor stricken with Covid-19 was running out of options. His family mounted a search for a donor whose plasma might help.
item.dc:creator: Audra D. S. Burch and Amy Harmon
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Basil Binns II, who had recovered from the coronavirus, was asked to donate plasma to help a stranger battling the infection.

item.title: Coronavirus World News: Live Tracker
item.description: Fighting fears and travel bans, countries and businesses are trying to rescue summer vacation. At Airbus, signs of trouble emerge.
item.media:description: A person who is suspected to have died of Covid-19 is buried on Wednesday in Sao Paulo, Brazil.

item.title: Airborne Coronavirus Detected in Wuhan Hospitals
item.description: While the RNA of the virus was found in tiny droplets in China, scientists don’t know if it was capable of transmitting the virus.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: A health worker sprayed disinfectant on a room that held coronavirus patients at the Red Cross hospital in Wuhan in March.

item.title: Trump’s Response to Virus Reflects a Long Disregard for Science
item.description: The president’s Covid-19 response has extended the administration’s longstanding practice of undermining scientific expertise for political purposes.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump arrived at the White House daily coronavirus briefing this month.

item.title: Coronavirus Live News Updates
item.description: A mall operator plans to reopen shopping centers, government officials debate whether some pro sports could resume, and schools balk at spring reopenings.

item.title: Unified in Coronavirus Lockdown, India Splinters Over Reopening
item.description: As India starts loosening restrictions, a once-broad consensus among leaders on how to proceed has weakened — and many people are staying home anyway.
item.dc:creator: Kai Schultz and Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: A checkpoint at the entrance to a market outside the Jama Masjid, a mosque in New Delhi, on Friday evening.

item.title: Abortion by Telemedicine: A Growing Option as Access to Clinics Wanes
item.description: The coronavirus has created a surge in demand for telemedicine of all types — including for a quietly expanding program for terminating pregnancies.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Michelle Mishina-Kunz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ashley Dale taking medications that were mailed to her through an abortion telemedicine service.

item.title: Spain, France, Greece: Coronavirus World News Live Updates
item.description: Even when governments don’t force people to stay home, fear does. Spain, France and Greece have announced plans to restart daily life, with caveats.
item.media:description: Walking past posters of the Tokyo 2020 Olympic Games in a subway station in Tokyo last week.

item.title: ‘Quarantine Fatigue’ Has More People Going Outside
item.description: New research shows that people are venturing out more frequently, and traveling farther from home.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn on Saturday.

item.title: In Race for a Coronavirus Vaccine, an Oxford Group Leaps Ahead
item.description: As scientists at the Jenner Institute prepare for mass clinical trials, new tests show their vaccine to be effective in monkeys.
item.dc:creator: David D. Kirkpatrick
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prof. Adrian Hill, the Jenner Institute’s director, in Oxford on Friday. His team is working to produce a coronavirus vaccine.

item.title: Live Coronavirus in the US Updates
item.description: More states gradually lift restrictions on some businesses even as cases remain high. A new testing plan falls short of what public health experts say is necessary.

item.title: Can Estrogen and Other Sex Hormones Help Men Survive Covid-19?
item.description: Men are more likely than women to die of the coronavirus, so scientists are treating them with something women have more of: female sex hormones.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.category: Renaissance School of Medicine at Stony Brook University
item.media:credit: Jake Michaels for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, where doctors will give a sex hormone to men sick with Covid-19.

item.title: Live Updates: Global Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: Even as the global death toll passed 200,000, countries are mapping out a return to public life. Health care workers in Mexico, India and other countries are facing attacks.
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain made his first public appearance since his hospitalization outside 10 Downing Street on Monday.

item.title: Can Antibody Tests Help End the Coronavirus Pandemic?
item.description: The tests are not reliable enough to guide policy on lockdowns and reopenings, experts said. But they can help model the spread of the virus.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A health care worker labels a blood sample for coronavirus antibody testing at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York.
